pull.title: optimization: Speed up TryParseHex by 300%
pull.body:
This pull request introduces optimizations to the `TryParseHex` function, focusing primarily on the ideal case (valid hexadecimal input without spaces).
A new benchmark, `TryParseHexBenchmark` was introduced in a separate commit.

Optimization Rationale:
- *Preallocation*: The main optimization preallocates the result vector based on the input string's length. This aims to completely avoid costly dynamic reallocations when no spaces are present.
- *Space Handling*: While focused on the ideal case, these optimizations should also improve performance when spaces are present since we avoid some IsSpace checks when characters parse correctly. In the presence of spaces, the final vector might be slightly larger than necessary.

------------

Before:
```
|           ns/base16 |            base16/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                1.60 |      623,238,893.11 |    0.3% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                1.65 |      606,747,566.34 |    0.6% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                1.60 |      626,149,544.07 |    0.3% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
```

After:
```
|           ns/base16 |            base16/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                0.54 |    1,866,216,380.08 |    0.9% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                0.53 |    1,871,755,872.12 |    0.5% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                0.53 |    1,875,106,332.14 |    0.1% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
```

events.message:
Add benchmark for TryParseHex

Running `make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin -filter=TryParseHexBenchmark` a few times results in:
```
|           ns/base16 |            base16/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                1.60 |      623,238,893.11 |    0.3% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                1.65 |      606,747,566.34 |    0.6% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                1.60 |      626,149,544.07 |    0.3% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
```

Preallocate result to in `TryParseHex` to avoid resizing

Running `make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin -filter=TryParseHexBenchmark` a few times results in:
```
|           ns/base16 |            base16/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                0.69 |    1,445,181,075.98 |    0.5% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                0.68 |    1,459,941,407.03 |    0.2% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                0.69 |    1,457,349,650.60 |    1.1% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
```

Optimize TryParseHex for ideal case by hiding IsSpace calls

Running `make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin -filter=TryParseHexBenchmark` a few times results in:
```
|           ns/base16 |            base16/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                0.54 |    1,866,216,380.08 |    0.9% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                0.53 |    1,871,755,872.12 |    0.5% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
|                0.53 |    1,875,106,332.14 |    0.1% |      0.01 | `TryParseHexBenchmark`
```

comments.body: we don't expect most hex strings to contain spaces so let's fall back to this when we can't parse the string instead
c1 validation can be done sooner
Ideally (when no spaces present) two characters will form a single byte - and when spaces are present, it will be less, so we can avoid reallocation by reserving `str.size() / 2`

Is it really worth it to change this? preallocation seems fine, given that it buys most of the speedup. However, the other reordering didn't change performance much, did it? Also, with modern compilers I'd be surprised if this made a large difference in any case?
